habitat_description:
Range includes southeastern Washington and southern Ohio south into Oregon, California, Nevada, Utah, western Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, and central Texas. In Mexico, Chihuahua, western Coahuila, Zacatecas, Durango, and into northeastern Jalisco (Camper and Dixon 1994 as referenced in Natureserve.org). Occupies the east of the Cascade Mountains; northeastern California, northern Nevada and Utah, northwestern Colorado, southern Idaho, central and eastern Oregon, and the Columbia Basin of south-central Washington. This species can be found in rocky areas of canyons and slopes, as well as in open flats (St. John 2002). The striped whipsnake is described as locally abundant in southeastern Oregon while scattered in central Oregon and lower elevations. This species occurs in the Columbia Basin in central Washington (Storm and Leonard 1995).  Commonly found in Semidesert Grassland, Great Basin Conifer Woodland, Interior Chaparral, Plaind and Great Basin Grassland. This species is also found across northern Arizona Upland Desertscrub and Petran Montane Conifer Forest. Found in the mountains of Harcuvar, Harquahala, Kofa, Pinaleno, and Santa Teresa (Brennan and Holycross 2009).

NW	-Grassland, herbaceous or shrubby land, conifer woodland, hardwood woodland, and rocky stream courses. Oregon White Oak, California Black Oak, and Pacific Madrone.

SW	-Desert, grassland, shrubby chaparral, mixed woodlands, sagebrush flats, pinon/juniper forest, rocky riparian zones. Ponderosa Pine, White Manzanita, Buckbrush, Deerbrush, and Bitterbrush.
